title: Youden's Demon is Sylvester's Problem
authors: Florian Frick, Andrew Newman, Wesley Pegden
abstract:
If four people with Gaussian-distributed heights stand at Gaussian positions
on the plane, the probability that there are exactly two people whose height is
above the average of the four is exactly the same as the probability that they
stand in convex position; both probabilities are $\frac 6 \pi
\arcsin\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)\approx .649$. We show that this is a special
case of a more general phenomenon: The problem of determining the position of
the mean among the order statistics of Gaussian random points on the real line
("Youden's demon problem") is the same as a natural generalization of
Sylvester's Four Point problem to Gaussian points in $\mathbb{R}^d$. Our main
tool is the observation that the Gale dual of independent samples in
$\mathbb{R}^d$ itself can be taken to be a set of independent points
(conditioned on barycenter at the origin) when the distribution of the points
is Gaussian.
